snippet: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.
abstract: Presidential advisory committee charged with examining the operations of the National Security Agency concludes that program to collect data on every phone call made in the United States should continue; report recommends broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections, and argues in favor of codifying and publicly announcing steps United States will take to protect the privacy of foreign citizens.

byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt and Charlie Savage contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: A presidential advisory committee’s recommendation of broad new restraints intended to increase privacy protections is a first sign that spying revelations may lead to changes.

headline.main: Obama Panel Said to Urge N.S.A. Curbs
